<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DeleteAllObjects:
```c
void OS_DeleteAllObjects(void)
{
    uint32 ObjectCount;
    uint32 TryCount;

    /*
     * Note - this is done in a loop because some objects depend on other objects
     * and you will not be able to delete the object until the ref count becomes zero.
     */
    TryCount = 0;
    while (true)
    {
        ObjectCount = 0;
        ++TryCount;

        /* Delete timers and tasks first, as they could be actively using other object types  */
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        /* Then try to delete all other remaining objects of any type */
        OS_ForEachObject(OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        if (ObjectCount == 0 || TryCount > 4)
        {
            break;
        }
        OS_TaskDelay(5);
    }
}
```

explanation: No explicit compiler/language extensions are used in the provided code. The fragment contains only standard C constructs: typedef aliasing of uint32_t, integer literals (0x09, 0x08, 0x01), macros, function calls, a while loop, increment operators, and comments. I checked for common vendor or compiler extensions that are commonly documented as extensions (for example: GCC/Clang __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions, labels-as-values, nested functions; MSVC __declspec; IAR pragmas or nonstandard keywords; named address-space qualifiers; extended integer widths or nonstandard storage-class specifiers). None of these appear. The use of true in while (true) is a standard boolean macro when <stdbool.h> is used (C99+); it is not a compiler extension. The macros like OS_OBJECT_TYPE_* and OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY and the typedef uint32 are user-defined and not language extensions. Therefore there are no fragments that require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions) based on the provided code.
